race.name: BWR Montana
race.tagline: Montana Rockies adventure‚Äî140km of mountain gravel, 2,800m elevation, Missoula scenery, waffles.

terrain.surface: 75% gravel, 25% paved roads. Montana Rockies‚Äîmountain terrain, technical sections. 2,800 m over 140 km. Missoula area. Technical rating: 4/5.

biased_opinion.summary: BWR Montana is Montana Rockies adventure‚Äî140 km, 2,800 m elevation. Founded ~2022. 75% gravel, 25% paved. Montana Rockies‚Äîmountain terrain, technical sections. 500-800 riders. Missoula, MT (great town, good airport access). August summer conditions (15-30¬∞C). BWR series entry ($180-$250). If you want Montana Rockies scenery with technical mountain gravel and waffles, this is it. If you need flat terrain, skip it. Mountain terrain is the challenge.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: BWR Montana is Montana Rockies mountain adventure. 140 km, 2,800 m, technical terrain. If you want Montana Rockies scenery with mountain gravel, this is it. If you need flat terrain, skip it. Missoula is great town with good airport access. BWR series = waffles at finish.

logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Missoula (MSO). Rental car or shuttle (15 km, 20-minute drive). Missoula lodging‚Äîbook early. Day-before packet pickup. Race August. Post-race waffles.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race waffles and party.
logistics.camping:
camping $20/night
- "Book early - everything sells out for race weekend" - Visit Missoula tourism

*Parking*
- Free at Fort Miss

course_description.character: 140 km, 2,800 m. 75% gravel, 25% paved. Montana Rockies‚Äîmountain terrain, technical sections. Technical rating: 4/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Montana Rockies Climbs
suffering_zones.description: Montana Rockies mountain terrain. 2,800 m cumulative elevation. Technical climbs.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Low gears. Pace conservatively. Technical skills required. 38-42mm tires.

suffering_zones.name: Mile 100+: Distance Fatigue
suffering_zones.description: 40 km to go. Legs tired. Mountain terrain continues.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Break into chunks. Focus on next aid. Mental toughness. Push through.

course_description.signature_challenge: 140 km + 2,800 m elevation + Montana Rockies mountain terrain.

history.origin_story: BWR Montana founded ~2022. Missoula, MT. 140 km, 500-800 riders. BWR series. Montana Rockies mountain gravel.
history.reputation: BWR series. Montana Rockies. Technical mountain terrain. Well-organized. Waffles at finish.

logistics.explanation: MikeMckinney notes "Check in and parking were excellent" at Fort Missoula Regional Park, with $20 camping available and MSO airport 15 minutes from downtown. Packet pickup Friday 4-8pm at DoubleTree avoids morning chaos, though booking early is mandatory‚Äîeverything sells out for race weekend.

length.explanation: Russell Finsterwald made his winning move after 105 miles on technical singletrack, finishing in 5:03:22 after launching his sprint early. Stella Hobbs "stormed away from the field on the first climb" and rode solo across the line in 5:31:33, showing the 87-mile distance breaks riders at different points. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: MikeMckinney describes "loose over hard gravel" where "if you got out of the ruts you were surfing around in the soft stuff." The final 4 miles of singletrack was "pretty rocky" with mandatory walking on steep sections, while eric_quiat found 42c tires "pretty perfect" for the varied terrain mix. More technical than most ‚Äî comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: MikeMckinney logged 7,900 feet of elevation gain with "19 climbs on my head unit" including one punchy 11% section around mile 90. Siena Hermon got a hand-up "at the bottom of a 900-foot climb," learning that accepting feeds before major ascents isn't ideal for heavier riders. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 86¬∞F and lows of 57¬∞F, with a 21% chance of rain on any given day. Flavia Oliveira Parks suffered electronic shifting failures at miles 40 and 97, getting stuck in single gears during the event. The exposed, windy sections demanded strategic racing to avoid "burning too many matches," while altitude and fast gravel conditions created additional challenges beyond pure weather. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: MikeMckinney warns "Don't forget Bozeman is at 4800 ft, and you ride up to 5500 feet numerous times which you will notice if you don't normally ride that high." Todd Melton observed "The elevation was definitely a challenge for a number of people" during the event. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: MikeMckinney encountered "a few non racer were using the trail riding against the flow" on the public singletrack, while some women's race riders faced an unexpected train stop that added four minutes. The course's exposed, windy sections and loose gravel surfaces demand real bike handling skills beyond pure fitness.

prestige.explanation: Russell Finsterwald praised the course diversity: "I'm a big fan of diverse courses like that where you have to use your technical skills, have to use group dynamics and tactics." Course architect Michael Marckx noted it produced "the closest top five finish in BWR history, as only 24 seconds separated the riders."

race_quality.explanation: Aid stations were "well stocked and appropriately placed, roughly at 22, 39, 67, 98" with "cold coke which was a bonus," reports MikeMckinney. Race organizers handle mechanicals like Flavia's shifting failures professionally, while the 13-hour cutoff accommodates most riders despite challenging terrain.

experience.explanation: Siena Hermon was "smiling ear to ear, descending through grassy fields lined with purple and yellow wildflowers" on the final singletrack. Flavia Oliveira Parks called it "by far the most amazing course they have ever put together" with "unreal" views despite mechanical difficulties.

community.explanation: Race reports note "Locals cheered from porches. Volunteers crushed it" throughout the course. MikeMckinney found "Decent vibes" at the finish with beer and coozies, while Todd Melton is "already planning to do it again" after experiencing Bozeman's hospitality and the event atmosphere.

field_depth.explanation: Todd Melton observed "The level of competition was higher than what I've seen in other events" with many participants having "participated in other BWR events this year." The 350-rider cap creates a competitive field where Russell Finsterwald's technical skills and sprint strength determined victory. Deeper field than most ‚Äî comparable to Badlands.

value.explanation: $215 standard entry includes waffle breakfast, four well-stocked aid stations, and post-ride amenities, but MikeMckinney notes the finish has "nothing that makes you hang out" beyond beer and a coozy. No cash prizes for a premium-priced gran fondo style event limits the competitive value proposition.

expenses.explanation: Missoula lodging hits $149/night at DoubleTree during race weekend, with budget options starting at $89 if you book early‚Äîbut 'everything sells out.' Direct flights from major hubs keep travel reasonable, though MSO isn't cheap. The $20 camping option at Fort Missoula helps budget-conscious masochists, but factor in tire replacement after the mud destroys your rubber. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Belgian Waffle Ride that actually lives up to its Belgian difficulty rating, where Montana's mountains separate the climbers from the pretenders.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Show up if you can sustain power at 7,000 feet and don't mind walking your bike through Hell's Kitchen when the grades hit double digits. This isn't about gravel handling‚Äîit's about whether your legs can push a big gear up endless climbs while your lungs remember what thin air feels like. Skip it if you think 9,000 feet of elevation sounds fun on paper.
final_verdict.alternatives: Leadville Trail 100 MTB gives you the same altitude suffering with actual prize money, while Unbound keeps you closer to sea level if you prefer speed over elevation. For pure climbing masochism without the gravel pretense, just ride Mount Washington Hillclimb and save yourself 86 miles of buildup.

videos.title: Big Sky, Big Wins: How Belgian Waffle Ride Montana Delivered a Double Victory
videos.description:
Welcome to the very first Belgian Waffle Ride Montana! We're in Bozeman, ready to explore what "Big Sky Country" truly means for gravel racing. I head into the race with the BWR Quad Crown series lead‚Ä¶ can I hold onto it? With 5+ miles of singletrack in the final stretch, this race is far from over at 8 miles to go. Get ready for Big Sky Country gravel and an epic finish!

Special thanks to: 
@Bikeflights

Use coupon code: MONTANA10

videos.title: BWR Montana 2025 - QUADRUPLE CROWN Ep. 4
videos.description:
Welcome to the 4th and final stop of the 2025 Belgian Waffle Ride Quadruple Crown and Inaugural event in Bozeman Montana!

Coming off a win at the 3rd stop in his home state of Utah, Joe Goettl looks to back that up with a good result here. This is his final shot at making his original goal of an overall series podium.

Thank you to everyone who's watched all the previous episodes and we really hope you'll enjoy this finale!

Directed and Produced by Isaac Johnston
https://www.instagram.com/isaacsjohnston/

Co Directed by Alex Strohl and RJ Bruni

Camera by Isaac Johnston

Extra Filming by Alex Strohl

Edited by RJ Bruni

Animations by Jon Cheseaux 
https://www.instagram.com/nordicventure/

videos.title: The Impossible Route Ep.3 - Bike Packing Across Montana (A Cycling Documentary)
videos.description:
Impossible Route ep.3, Glacier to Tetons is a Cycling Documentary that covers a 5 day adventure across the state of Montana. In this episode we bring along the very fast and very capable pro cyclist, Eddie Anderson. 

Eddie is an active pro for the team Alpicen Fenix, an Eagle Scout, and a genuine great human. Eddie brings world tour fitness to give context on just how hard the Impossible routes really are. 

Jeremiah Bishop, Eddie Anderson, and The Vegan Cyclist embark on a 5 day journey across the unridden dirt roads and trails of Montana. Starting in glacier national park, the 3 ride Canyon gravel bikes packed down with everything they need to survive the trip. 

Most of the routes were not accessible by vehicle, so the riders needed to be ready for getting out of sticky situations. This cycling documentary is narrated and edited by Tyler (The Vegan Cyclist) but so much work into this project by so many people. 

Travis, who was a rider in ep.2 helped a ton with logistics and filming during the trip. Preston got great still photos, and Josh was a wizard with the main videography. A huge THANK YOU to the team behind this and we hope you enjoy this story. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
FAQS:
:Q: What bikes where ridden? 
:A: JB & VC rode the Canyon Grizzle and Eddie rode the Canyon Grail

:Q: What size tires were ran?
:A: The crew ran IRC Double Cross 44s 

:Q: What was the sleep set up like?
:A: To save on weight, the riders carried as little as possible. VC had a hammock and a light sleeping bag. JB had a sleep pad and a light sleeping bag. And Eddie bright a full on tent and sub zero sleeping bag. 

:Q: What did you eat on the rides? 
:A: Outside of Flow Formulas in our bottles, the riders had to stick up at the random stores along the route. Each day only had 1 stop for fueling, so high calorie foods were the ticket. JB did have a jet boil so heating up water for freeze dried food was great as well. 

:Q: How ‚ÄúREAL‚Äù is this? How much do you FAKE the drama? 
:A: We don‚Äôt fake anything, we ride the ride and let the story play out as it happens. This route had the riders by themselves for most of the day so the safety net of a film crew is rare. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
DONATE : Look, these are tough to make. Even with sponsor support, the budget for each episode is crazy high. If you felt like this was worth a buck or 2, any support would be amazing. 
( https://www.paypal.com/paypalme/vegancyclist )

quotes.text: With 5+ miles of singletrack in the final stretch, this race is far from over at 8 miles to go. Four may enter, but who knows how many will come out. It's a lot of corners to blow.

I think for a BWR, I was expecting it to be a little bit rougher and gnarlier, but so far it's definitely looking to be like a fast kind of road racy style race, but there are a ton of rollers, so it's definitely not going to be an easy race.

I look to Belgian waffle rides as events that really bring the best courses that we race on all season. They're the most encompassing of everything that I think gravel racing should be. Like you have a lot of single track out there, just challenging unroad sectors that pop up out of nowhere.

terrain_notes.text: The course includes a lot of single track sections that pop up throughout the race, creating technical challenges 100 miles into the event when riders are fatigued.

gear_mentions.text: Most riders opted for 45mm tires. One rider ran Teras 45s and discussed whether to use J1 RS at 45mm width versus other 45mm options.

race_day_tips.text: The race will likely break up into small groups all day and probably be down to three or four riders going into the single track sections.

additional_quotes.text: I look to Belgian waffle rides as events that really bring the best courses that we race on all season. They're the most encompassing of everything that I think gravel racing should be. Like you have a lot of single track out there, just challenging unroad sectors that pop up out of nowhere.
Having gotten second at BWR Arizona and then having a decent ride in BWR California getting seventh, I come into the weekend with the lead in the series which is pretty cool. This is the final stop.

rider_intel.search_text: BWR Montana serves as the final stop in the Belgian Waffle Ride Triple Crown series, taking place in Big Sky Country around Bozeman, Montana. Riders describe the course as encompassing everything gravel racing should be, featuring significant single track sections that create technical challenges, especially when riders hit them 100 miles into the race while fatigued. The terrain includes challenging unroad sectors that pop up unexpectedly throughout the course. Most competitive riders opt for 45mm tires to handle the varied terrain. The race typically breaks down into small groups throughout the day, with expectations that only three or four riders will remain together heading into the technical single track sections. The event attracts strong competition as riders vie for both individual race wins and overall series standings.
